greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Infinite Redheffer matrix read by upwards antidiagonals.
comment: Note that Redheffer's matrix (1977) is actually given by A077049: the first row starts with a single 1. We follow the nomenclature of Wilf, Dana, Vaughan and Weisstein, which uses the transpose and sets the first column to all-1. - _R. J. Mathar_, Jul 22 2017
The determinant of the n X n Redheffer matrix is given by Mertens's function A002321(n) [Barrett].

For n > 1, replacing a(n,n) with 0 in the Redheffer matrix and taking the determinant gives Moebius(n) = A008683(n). The number of permutations with nonzero contribution to this determinant is given by A002033. For first few n, these permutations are shown in the sequences A144193 to A144201. - _Mats Granvik_, Sep 14 2008
The determinant that is the Moebius function was discovered by reading the blog post "The Mobius function is strongly orthogonal to nilsequences" by _Terence Tao_. - _Mats Granvik_, Jan 24 2009
reference: R. C. Vaughan, On the eigenvalues of Redheffer's matrix I, in: Number Theory with an Emphasis on the Markoff Spectrum (Provo, Utah, 1991), 283-296, Lecture Notes in Pure and Appl. Math., 147, Dekker, New-York, 1993.
link: Enrique Pérez Herrero, Rows n = 1..100 of triangle, flattened

Herbert S. Wilf, The Redheffer matrix of a partially ordered set, The Electronic Journal of Combinatorics 11(2) (2004), #R10
formula: a(i,j) = 1 if j=1 or i|j; 0 otherwise.
maple: for m from d-1 to 1 by -1 do
mathematica: A143104[n_] := Redheffer[i[n], j[n]]; (* _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Apr 13 2010 *)
Table[a[i-j+1, j], {i, 1, 14}, {j, 1, i}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Aug 07 2018 *)
